Comments_List: How to identify animals by skull.

Mammalogy is a wonderful course where you go through the whole phylogeny of mammals and learn about every family! The lectures give you a broad overview of features of different mammals and in labs you will look at skins and skulls and be able to identitify them by the end of the course.
Deep understanding of mammal systematics and diversity
This was a great class. Learned a lot about mammals. Obviously. Dr. Sargis is a great lecturerer. Also learned a lot about evolution which was a previous gap in my knowledge.
The strengths were the active engagement with mammal bones and utilizing the specimens in the Peabody Museum

Strengths: lectures and lab were both great
Weaknesses: too much material before each test. Would recommend more lab exams with fewer families on each.

Yes but with caution. This is the first class that "low workload" did NOT correlate with an easy class. Over a third of the class was composed of PhD students who want to pursue a similar field for a living. As a result, the exams were challenging and not curved unless someone didn't get a 100 (which someone always did). I took the class Cr/D and that was a fantastic decision on my part, who came in knowing nothing about specimen identification. Also, the class is less a mammology course and far more an anthropology course with a smattering of fun facts about an animal.
Yes! Take it-- there': no other class like it! Both labs and lectures will leave you feeling fresh and inspired.
Absolutely, but only if you are entirely committed to it going in.
Yes, definitely. Should be offered in several sections for more people.
